content: The "Air Cargo Security Improvement Act of 2018" establishes the Air Cargo Security Division. The Air Cargo Security Improvement Act of 2018 establishes a new section in the United States Code, requiring the Transportation Security Administration to create an air cargo security division within 90 days. This division will handle policy and engagement with stakeholders, led by an executive service individual and staffed with at least four full-time equivalents. Staffing will be done using existing TSA personnel. The Air Cargo Security Improvement Act of 2018 mandates the creation of an air cargo security division by the Transportation Security Administration within 90 days. The division will be led by an executive service individual and staffed with at least four full-time equivalents, utilizing existing TSA personnel. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. The Air Cargo Security Improvement Act of 2018 requires the Transportation Security Administration to establish an air cargo security division within 90 days. The division will be headed by an executive service individual and staffed with at least four full-time equivalents, using existing TSA personnel. A feasibility study and pilot program for emerging technologies are also mandated. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration, in coordination with the Department of Homeland Security, must submit a feasibility study on expanding computed tomography technology for screening air cargo on passenger aircraft. The study will assess leveraging existing systems, costs, and benefits of using this technology. The Transportation Security Administration will initiate a pilot program using new screening technologies, including computed tomography, to enhance air cargo security screening outcomes. The Transportation Security Administration will provide updates to congressional committees every 6 months on the progress of implementing a pilot program using new screening technologies for air cargo security. Definitions for terms like "air carrier," "air transportation," and "foreign air carrier" are specified in this section. The terms "interstate air commerce" and "interstate air transportation" are defined in section 40102 of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 4. AIR CARGO REGULATION REVIEW. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration must submit a report to Congress within 150 days of the enactment of the Act, reviewing the effectiveness of the Certified Cargo Screening Program in addressing evolving threats to air cargo and vulnerabilities in the program. The report should also include actions to address any findings and plans for new rulemaking if necessary. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the Department of Homeland Security's air cargo pre-screening processes, pilot program, risk-based strategy, and information sharing procedures within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a review of the Known Shipper Program will be conducted. SEC. 6. KNOWN SHIPPER PROGRAM REVIEW. The Administrator will request a review of the Known Shipper Program by the Air Cargo Subcommittee to assess its security and recommend modifications or elimination in light of full implementation of 100 percent screening. The findings and recommendations will be reported to the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration. The curr_chunk states: "Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk."
